sub.mono:

  • Disseminated infection due to Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare group; Prophylaxis - HIV infection: (secondary prevention) 300 mg ORALLY daily in combination with clarithromycin 500 mg ORALLY twice daily and ethambutol 15 mg/kg ORALLY daily

  • HIV infection - Tuberculosis: 150 mg ORALLY every other day OR 150 mg ORALLY 3 times weekly in combination with ritonavir
  • HIV infection - Tuberculosis: 450 mg ORALLY once daily OR 600 mg ORALLY 3 times weekly in combination with efavirenz

  • HIV infection - Tuberculosis: 300 mg ORALLY once daily OR 300 mg ORALLY 3 times weekly in combination with nevirapine

sub.mono: renal impairment: 50% dose reduction for severe renal impairment (CrCl less than 30 mL/min)

sub.mono:

Disseminated infection due to Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare group; Prophylaxis - HIV infection

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Concomitant use with delavirdine
  • Concomitant use with rilpivirine
  • Concomitant use with voriconazole
  • Hypersensitivity to rifabutin or to any other rifamycins

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, including mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported and may occur over 2 months from last dose; discontinue use if suspected
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Neutropenia has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- Thrombocytopenia has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Not recommended in patients with known active TB; may lead to TB that is resistant to rifabutin and rifampin
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Uveitis may occur; monitoring recommended during concurrent use of macrolide antibiotic or fluconazole and related compounds; interruption may be necessary
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Etravirine when used in combination with a ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitor; avoid use
  • -- Cobicistat/elvitegravir/emtricitabine/tenofovir is not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (11%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile diarrhea, Loss of taste
  • Ophthalmic:Ocular discoloration, Uveitis

Serious
  • Hematologic:Neutropenia (25%), Thrombocytopenia (5%)
  • Immunologic:Systemic lupus erythematosus

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: The antimicrobial activity of rifabutin is produced by inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase and subsequent initiation of transcription . This results in inhibition of protein synthesis . Rifabutin has a broad spectrum of antimicrobial activity . This includes activity against mycobacteria (atypical mycobacteria, including the Mycobacterium avium complex [MAC], Mycobacterium leprae, and Mycobacterium tuberculosis), a variety of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, Chlamydia trachomatis, and Toxoplasma gondii .

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono: Systemic: Readily absorbed; high fat food slows absorption

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono: Systemic: Vd: 9.3 plus or minus 1.5 L/kg

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Systemic: 30% fecal; 5% unchanged in the urine; 5% unchanged in the bile; 53% in urine as metabolites .
  • In dialysis-Hemodialysis is not expected to enhance elimination .
  • Systemic: Fecal: 30%, 5% unchanged; Renal: 53% metabolites, 5% unchanged

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Prevention of disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) disease in patients with advanced HIV is indicative of efficacy
  • CBC with differential
  • Signs and symptoms of uveitis, especially with coadministration of macrolides antibiotics or fluconazole and related compounds

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
RIFABUTIN
OVERDOSE: Overdose information is limited. Daily doses of 1 g or greater have resulted in a syndrome of arthralgia/arthritis. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Uveitis, rash and skin and urine discoloration have been frequently reported with rifabutin therapy. Other reported adverse effects include neutropenia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia, ageusia, anorexia, diarrhea and flatulence.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
RIFABUTIN
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal.
  • Myelosuppression: Leukopenia, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia have been reported with therapeutic use but not after overdose. Filgrastim: 5 mcg/kg/day IV or subQ. Sargramostim: 250 mcg/meter(2)/day IV over 4 hours; transfusions of packed red blood cells and platelets may be useful if bleeding occurs.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor CBC with differential, liver enzyme levels and fluid/electrolyte status in symptomatic patients.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Rifabutin is highly protein-bound and is extensively distributed into tissues; therefore, enhanced elimination techniques, including hemodialysis, hemoperfusion or forced diuresis, are not expected to be of any benefit following overdose.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
RIFABUTIN
TOXICITY: A specific toxic dose has not been established. A syndrome of arthralgia/arthritis has been reported following daily doses of at least 1 g. THERAPEUTIC: ADULT - 150 to 300 mg/day.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient that drug may cause brown-orange discoloration of fluids/tissues (skin, urine, feces, sputum, tears, and sweat) and permanently stain soft contact lenses.
  • Drug may cause rash, diarrhea, taste changes, dyspepsia, or nausea.
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of active tuberculosis or mycobacterium avium complex disease (persistent cough, hemoptysis, fever, chills, weight loss, weakness, fatigue, chest pain, or night sweats).
  • Instruct patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (watery or bloody diarrhea, with or without fever) during or after discontinuation.
  • Advise patient, if prone to nausea, to take with food.
  • Advise patient there are multiple drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult a healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
